flow.context: Tara Nieslanik is a Property Manager at Luxury Estate Managers of Aspen (LEMA), a premium, confidentiality-focused estate/property management firm in Aspen, CO. She relocated from Nebraska and has a competitive sports background up to the professional level — described as goal-oriented and teamwork-driven. Key org detail: Britton Nieslanik (VP) shares her last name — likely family — and Sarah Korpela is President. LEMA's tech stack and unit count are unknown; they market meticulous care across high-value homes. No strong personal connection to Sam, so lead with industry proximity in the Aspen luxury market. Sam was just skiing Jackson Hole in January — light ski-town rapport is available if needed.

opener.label: OPENER
opener.say: Hey Tara — I've been talking with a few property managers in the Aspen luxury market. It's Sam Parks with RapidEye. Have you heard my name tossed around at all?
opener.note: You're calling her direct cell (402 area code — Nebraska number). Feet-up energy. Casual, peer-to-peer. Don't rush. Let the 'heard my name' question hang.

branches.label: No / Who? / Don't think so
Yes / Maybe / Sounds familiar
Bad timing / I'm busy / Can't talk
Who is this? / What company?

not_heard_name.label: NOT HEARD — PAIN TRIGGER
not_heard_name.say: Ha — guess I'm not as popular as I thought. Well, the reason for my call — I work with a few other property managers who run luxury homes, pretty similar setup to what you guys do at LEMA. And the thing I keep hearing is the same headache — after every turnover or walkthrough there's this pile of photos, and somebody's gotta go through every single one to make sure nothing got missed. A scratch on a countertop, a stain on the upholstery, a missing remote — and in Aspen with the caliber of homes you're managing, if something slips through, you're the one hearing about it from the homeowner.
not_heard_name.note: PAUSE HERE. Let the pain land. Wait for her to react before continuing. If she jumps in, let her talk. If silence, continue to the solution and CTA.

branches.label: She reacts / Yeah that's real / Mmhm
Silence — continue
We already have a process for that
I'm not really the right person for this
Not interested / We're all set

deliver_solution_cta.label: SOLUTION + CTA
deliver_solution_cta.say: We built a tool that plugs into whatever you're already using and flags that stuff automatically — damage, missing items, condition changes — so you're not eyeballing two hundred photos hoping you don't miss something. Would you be open to taking a look sometime when I'm not cold calling you out of the blue?
deliver_solution_cta.note: One sentence on the solution, then straight to the CTA. Keep it light. 'When I'm not cold calling you' disarms and gets a smile.

branches.label: Yeah / Sure / That could be interesting
How does it work? / Tell me more
We already have a process
I'm not the right person
Not interested / No thanks
Send me an email

heard_name.label: HEARD NAME — EXPLORE
heard_name.say: Oh nice — well normally we'd be working with someone like you. What'd you hear?
heard_name.note: Let her talk. Whatever she says, bridge into discovery or the pain trigger depending on her energy.

branches.label: Shares what she heard
Not sure / Can't remember exactly
Someone mentioned you / Got an email

bad_timing.label: BAD TIMING — RESCHEDULE
bad_timing.say: Totally hear you — would it be a terrible idea if I tried you again tomorrow or later this week? When's less hectic?
bad_timing.note: Lock a specific callback day and time. Don't accept 'sometime next week.' Get a real answer.

branches.label: Gives a time / Sure try Thursday
Just tell me what it's about quick
Don't call back / Not interested

clarify_who.label: CLARIFY — RE-INTRO
clarify_who.say: Yeah totally — Sam Parks, I'm with a company called RapidEye. We work with a bunch of property management teams that run high-end homes. I've been chatting with a few folks in the Aspen market and your name came up. Have you heard of us at all?
clarify_who.note: Re-anchor calmly. Don't rush or sound flustered. Sound unbothered.

branches.label: No / What do you do?
Oh okay / Go ahead
Not interested

warm_discovery.label: WARM — ASK QUESTIONS
warm_discovery.say: Nice — so just to make sure I'm not wasting your time, can I ask a couple quick questions? What does your process look like right now when you're checking on your properties — like after a turnover or a regular walkthrough, how are you guys documenting condition?
warm_discovery.note: STOP PITCHING. She's warm. Ask questions and listen. You want to learn: (1) how they document condition, (2) who reviews photos, (3) what falls through the cracks, (4) whether this is STR turnover or estate walkthroughs. LEMA may be more estate management than pure STR.

branches.label: Describes process (photos, checklists, etc.)
Our cleaners / team takes photos
I'm not sure I'm the right person
Why do you ask? / What's this about?

discovery_deepen.label: DIG DEEPER — WHO REVIEWS
discovery_deepen.say: Got it — and who on the team is actually reviewing those photos? Is it you going through them, or does someone else check after they come in?
discovery_deepen.note: Map the workflow. If she reviews photos herself, the pain is personal. If it rolls up to Britton or Sarah, you may need to go there.

branches.label: I review them / It's on the PMs
It varies / Everyone chips in
Sarah or Britton handles that

discovery_photo_review.label: PHOTO REVIEW PROCESS
discovery_photo_review.say: Yeah that's what I hear from most teams. So when those photos come in — how many are you looking at per property? And what happens when something does get missed? Does the homeowner catch it, or does it come up at the next check-in?
discovery_photo_review.note: Get her to say the pain out loud. In luxury Aspen, a missed scratch on a custom table is a five-figure conversation with an owner.

branches.label: Admits things slip through / Yeah it happens
We're pretty thorough / Not a big issue
It's a lot of photos / Overwhelming

discovery_pain_confirm.label: CONFIRM THE PAIN — VOLUME
discovery_pain_confirm.say: So you're personally going through these after each check — how many properties are you managing right now? And in peak season, how often are you doing walkthroughs across all of them?
discovery_pain_confirm.note: Get a number. Volume makes the pain real. Even 10 properties with regular walkthroughs and 30-50 photos each is hundreds of photos a week. Aspen peak season (ski and summer) means compressed timelines.

branches.label: Gives a number / It's a lot in season
Not that many / It's manageable
We do more estate management than STR turnovers

pain_acknowledged.label: PAIN CONFIRMED — BRIDGE TO CTA
pain_acknowledged.say: Yeah that's exactly what I keep hearing. The photos are there but nobody has time to really go through every single one — and with the homes you're managing in Aspen, a missed issue doesn't stay small for long. That's literally what we built RapidEye for — it runs through those photos automatically and flags anything that looks off. No workflow change on your end. Would it make sense to hop on a quick call this week so I can show you what it actually looks like? I could walk you through what a couple other luxury PM teams are doing with it.
pain_acknowledged.note: Pitch the meeting, not the product. 'What other luxury PM teams are doing' is the value offer — she gets intel even if she never buys. If she wants to involve leadership, that's a win too.

branches.label: Yeah let's do it / Sure
I'd need to loop in Britton or Sarah
Can you send me something first?
I don't think we need that

pivot_estate_management.label: PIVOT — ESTATE MANAGEMENT ANGLE
pivot_estate_management.say: Oh totally — and that actually might be even more relevant. A lot of the estate management teams we talk to are doing regular walkthroughs and seasonal check-ins on homes where the owners might not be there for months, right? Same challenge though — you're documenting condition every time, taking photos, and someone has to verify nothing's changed between visits. Especially with vendors coming through, maintenance work happening — things shift and nobody catches it until the owner shows up. Does that sound like what you deal with?
pivot_estate_management.note: LEMA is estate management first, not a pure STR operator. Pivot the use case to ongoing condition monitoring, seasonal inspections, and vendor accountability. Same tech, different framing. This might resonate more than turnover language.

branches.label: Yeah that's more what we do
We have that covered
You should talk to Sarah or Britton about that

restate_value.label: RESTATE VALUE SIMPLY
restate_value.say: Good question — basically we work with property management teams who are already taking photos during walkthroughs or turnovers. Our software goes through those photos automatically and catches stuff that gets missed — damage, missing items, condition changes. It's been a big deal for teams managing luxury homes because the stakes are higher when something slips. I was curious how you guys handle that at LEMA.
restate_value.note: Keep it plain. She asked what it's about — tell her, then redirect with a question to get her talking.

branches.label: Oh interesting / Okay
We don't really have that problem
You should talk to someone else

objection_have_process.label: OBJECTION — HAVE A PROCESS
objection_have_process.say: That totally makes sense — with the caliber of homes you manage, you'd have to have something solid in place. Just so nobody from my team bugs you again — is it more that you're fully happy with how it's working and nothing's slipping through, or is it that switching up anything right now would just be a headache?
objection_have_process.note: Miyagi method. Agree first, then split. If she says 'it works,' she might still reveal friction. If she says 'switching is hard,' that's a timing objection you can work with.

branches.label: It works fine / We're good
Switching would be a pain / Timing isn't great
I mean stuff does slip through sometimes
I really don't have time for this

objection_not_interested.label: OBJECTION — NOT INTERESTED
objection_not_interested.say: Totally get it — I should've assumed you'd be all set, otherwise you probably would've reached out to us. Just so nobody from my team cold calls you again — is it that this just isn't a problem you're focused on right now, or is it more that cold calls are just the worst and I caught you at a bad moment?
objection_not_interested.note: Agree, don't fight. Split the objection. If it's the cold call itself, you can recover. If it's genuinely not relevant, try a referral or exit gracefully.

branches.label: It's just not relevant to us
Yeah cold calls are annoying / Bad timing
I'm not the right person for this
Please don't call again

permission_fallback.label: PERMISSION FALLBACK
permission_fallback.say: Yeah totally fair — I mean it is a cold call, I get it. Can I get just thirty seconds to tell you why I actually reached out? And you can totally hang up on me if it's not a fit.
permission_fallback.note: This is your lifeline. If she gives 30 seconds, go straight to a tight version of the pain trigger in not_heard_name. Be quick and land the pain fast.

branches.label: Fine / Go ahead / Thirty seconds
No / I really can't right now

not_right_person.label: NOT THE RIGHT PERSON — REFERRAL
not_right_person.say: Totally hear you — and I appreciate you telling me that instead of just sitting through a pitch. When it comes to how you guys handle inspections or condition tracking across your properties, who would be the best person to talk to? Would that be more of a Britton or Sarah thing?
not_right_person.note: Tara and Britton share the last name Nieslanik — likely family. Drop Britton's first name casually to signal you know the team. If she gives you Sarah (President) or Britton (VP), ask for a warm intro. This is actually a great outcome — a PM referring you up to leadership.

branches.label: Talk to Britton / Sarah
Gives another name
I don't know / Just email the office
I can mention it to them

get_warm_intro.label: GET THE WARM INTRO
get_warm_intro.say: Perfect — would you be able to give them a quick heads up that I'll be reaching out? That way it's not another random cold call for them. And honestly if there's anything specific you think would make it land better — like something you guys have been dealing with — that'd help me put together something actually useful instead of a generic pitch.
get_warm_intro.note: Turn Tara into an internal champion. If she shares a pain point, you have insider intel for the call to Britton/Sarah. Get the referral name confirmed, and try to learn when she'll mention it to them.

branches.label: Sure I'll mention it / Yeah I can do that
Just call them / Here's their number
I'm not sure they'd be interested

internal_champion.label: INTERNAL CHAMPION
internal_champion.say: That would honestly be amazing. If you mention it to them, I'll follow up with a quick email so they have something to look at. Would it be cool if I sent you a one-pager you could forward along? Sometimes that's way easier than trying to explain what some random guy pitched you on the phone.
internal_champion.note: Make it easy for her. Give her a tool — the one-pager or email — so she doesn't have to sell it internally. She offered to champion; remove all friction.

branches.label: Yeah send it over / Sure
I'll just tell them to call you

confirm_referral_details.label: CONFIRM REFERRAL DETAILS
confirm_referral_details.say: Awesome — I'll reach out to them this week. I've got tara at luxuryema dot com for you — is that the best email to send the info to? And should I be reaching out to Britton or Sarah first — or both?
confirm_referral_details.note: Confirm her email. Get clarity on who to call. You already have Britton's direct line (970-948-9896) and Sarah's (970-379-4705). If she says Britton, that's probably the easier path since they're likely family.

branches.label: Confirms email and referral target
Just email them directly / Gives their info

referral_to_leadership.label: REFERRAL TO BRITTON OR SARAH
referral_to_leadership.say: That makes total sense — this is probably more of a Britton or Sarah decision. Would it make sense for me to reach out to them directly? And if you could give them a heads up, that'd honestly go a long way so I'm not just cold calling them out of nowhere.
referral_to_leadership.note: Britton Nieslanik (VP) shares Tara's last name — likely family. If Tara suggests Britton, ask: 'Would Sarah want to be looped in too, or is Britton the one who'd own this?' Get both names if possible.

branches.label: Yeah reach out to Britton / Sarah
I'll mention it to them
Just email them

sell_test_drive.label: SELL THE TEST DRIVE
sell_test_drive.say: Totally get it — you're probably not switching anything right now and I respect that. But here's what I've seen work — the people who end up loving this are the ones who saw it before peak season hit, so when budget opens up they already know what's on their list. Would you be open to just taking a look? Fifteen minutes, I'll show you how it works, worst case you steal some ideas for your own process and we part as friends.
sell_test_drive.note: Low pressure. Position the meeting as intelligence gathering, not a buying decision. 'Before peak season' is a timing lever — Aspen has ski season and summer season, both high-intensity.

branches.label: Okay sure / Yeah I guess
I'd need to involve Britton or Sarah
Just send me an email
No I'm good

soft_pitch_cta.label: SOFT CTA — SOCIAL PROOF
soft_pitch_cta.say: Totally respect that. Look — if nothing else, I could walk you through what a couple other luxury property management teams are doing with their documentation. We work with a group in New York managing about two hundred high-end homes and another East Coast company with around six hundred. Worst case you get some ideas for your own process. Would a quick fifteen minutes be worth it?
soft_pitch_cta.note: Social proof play. NYC (200 luxury homes) and East Coast (600 properties) are real traction. In luxury PM, what peers are doing matters. If she bites, book it. If not, try referral or exit clean.

branches.label: Okay that could be interesting
I'd want Britton or Sarah involved
Send me something and I'll look at it
I'll pass / Not right now

last_ditch_value.label: LAST DITCH — VALUE OFFER
last_ditch_value.say: Totally hear you. I won't take any more of your time. One thing — we put together a quick breakdown of how a few luxury property managers are handling their inspection workflows differently. Happy to send it over, no pitch attached. If it's useful, great. If not, no hard feelings. Cool if I shoot that to your email?
last_ditch_value.note: Last play before exit. Pure value, zero commitment. If she says yes, you have an email thread and a reason to follow up. If she says no, exit gracefully.

branches.label: Sure send it over
No thanks / I'm good

book_meeting.label: BOOK THE MEETING
book_meeting.say: Awesome — let me pull up my calendar. How does Thursday look for you? I could do morning or afternoon — what's better on your end?
book_meeting.note: Pick a specific day. Give two options. Lock it NOW. Once she picks, confirm it back and say you'll send the invite immediately. If she wants to include Britton or Sarah, offer to send the invite to all of them.

branches.label: Gives a day/time
Let me check / I'll get back to you
Send me an invite and I'll confirm

pin_down_meeting.label: PIN DOWN THE MEETING
pin_down_meeting.say: Tell you what — I'll shoot over an invite for Thursday at ten. If that doesn't work, just let me know and we'll move it around. Sound fair? And is tara at luxuryema dot com the best email for the invite?
pin_down_meeting.note: Don't leave it open-ended. It's easier to move a meeting than to schedule one from scratch. Confirm her email and send the invite before hanging up.

branches.label: Okay sounds good
I really need to check first

meeting_confirmed.label: MEETING BOOKED — WRAP UP
meeting_confirmed.say: Perfect — sending that over right now. Tara, really appreciate you taking my call. Even if it turns out it's not a fit, I think you'll get some useful stuff out of it. Talk soon.
meeting_confirmed.note: STOP SELLING. You got the meeting. Be grateful, be brief, hang up. Send the calendar invite immediately. If she mentioned Britton or Sarah, include them on the invite or follow up with them separately within 24 hours.

send_email.label: SEND ME AN EMAIL
send_email.say: Totally fair — I'll send something over. One quick question before I do though — what would be most useful to include so it's not just another generic email sitting in your inbox? Like is it more about how it actually works, or would you rather see what results other luxury teams are getting?
send_email.note: Accept the email ask but use the question to learn what she cares about. Then ask: 'And should I copy Britton or Sarah on it, or just send it to you?' This might get you another contact.

branches.label: Tells you what to include / Just send whatever
Copy Britton or Sarah too

ask_copy_leadership.label: ASK ABOUT COPYING LEADERSHIP
ask_copy_leadership.say: Got it — I'll tailor it. And should I copy Britton or Sarah on it too, or just send it your way?
ask_copy_leadership.note: This is a subtle play to get the email in front of decision-makers. If she says yes, you just got a warm email intro to the VP or President.

branches.label: Yeah copy them / Sure add Britton
Just me is fine

confirm_email_exit.label: CONFIRM EMAIL AND EXIT
confirm_email_exit.say: Perfect — I'll put something together and send it to tara at luxuryema dot com. I'll follow up later this week to make sure it landed. Appreciate your time, Tara — talk soon.
confirm_email_exit.note: Confirm the email. State you'll follow up — sets expectation for a second touch. Send the email within 30 minutes with specific meeting time suggestion. Note everything she said in CRM.

lock_callback.label: LOCK CALLBACK TIME
lock_callback.say: Perfect — I'll try you then. Is this the best number to reach you on? And just so you know who's calling — it's Sam Parks, RapidEye. Talk to you soon, Tara.
lock_callback.note: Confirm the number (402-440-7682). Repeat your name so she recognizes it next time. Put the callback in your calendar immediately with notes on this attempt.

end_referral_positive.label: REFERRAL CONFIRMED — EXIT
end_referral_positive.say: Really appreciate it, Tara. I'll reach out to them this week and send you that info too. Thanks for taking my call — talk soon.
end_referral_positive.note: You got a referral — that's a win. Send Tara the follow-up email within 30 minutes. Call Britton (970-948-9896) or Sarah (970-379-4705) within 24-48 hours. Open that call with: 'I was chatting with Tara and she suggested I give you a call.' That turns the next call into a warm call.

graceful_exit.label: GRACEFUL EXIT
graceful_exit.say: Totally understand. If anything changes down the road, I'm easy to find — Sam Parks with RapidEye. Appreciate your time, Tara.
graceful_exit.note: Don't burn the bridge. Log the outcome in CRM. Consider a non-pushy follow-up email in 1-2 weeks. If you close other Aspen PMs, circle back — social proof in a small market travels fast.
